Everything is possible my dear, the Internet system there is governed by Proxy Servers since it was available to the public, it is only part of the evolution of the tools to allow for Man-in-the-Middle monitoring and interception for messaging apps content.
But I mean how could they get the content of Whatsapp messages? All they should get is encrypted data!

This is the Blue Coat Encrypted Traffic Management appliance, targeted to Medium Businesses and Enterprises, just think that the same company that now owns Blue Coat "Symantec" is the same one owning the most important Certificate Authority in the world "VeriSign" and has internal access to the private keys of the Root Certificates to most of the sites on the Internet.
So just think if Blue Coat (or similar company) have a super-sized super-fat super-confidential contract with a government to supply ISP-sized equipment to do exactly what you are seeing, it is not even technically difficult anymore.
If there are products that can break encryption this easy, I guess there is no purpose to encrypt anymore!

Nope, these tools are-governments sized, but governments are not the only threat that needs encryption, and this is not related to all kinds of encryption (for example, if you want to stay Anonymous in the Internet, TOR is still very usable (not bullet-proof, but mostly good enough), if you need files encryption, VeraCrypt (one of the forks of TrueCrypt) is highly recommended, or use 7-Zip and just make password-encrypted .7z archives.

And you can use a VPN tool to circumvent such Man-in-the-Middle interception, I don't recommend a commercial offer here, get yourself a small Linux server using a Cloud service and setup your own VPN using generated certificates (and don't transfer it using emails or ftp, use ssh or a normal view and copy and paste from the terminal screen.

most probably a prank pulled by someone who was able to get a list of people's names and their phone numbers.
As far as I know, to spy on https traffic you need a trusted certificate of some sort, and I think even that can be detected if you do certificate pinning.
For the end-to-end encryption in WhatsApp though you need to intercept the initial key exchange, and even that can be detected by meeting your friend in-person to see if the keys match. I've read however that someone could change the key mid-conversation and WhatsApp wouldn't tell you by default, you can however go to Settings > Account > Security to make WhatsApp notify you when such a thing happens.

I assume it's a prank, end to end encryption so far proved strong ability of defeating any trials to intercept message between both sides, even from the ISP itself.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-to-end_encryption

On the governments side, especially the ones allied with USA, it is not that well-proven, just remember PRISM
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program)

Its definitley a prank. 
1. Whatsapp and snapchat use end to end encryption, and these are notoriously difficult if not impossible to decrypt using man in the middle.
2. One of the messages misspelled Whatsapp (Whatsabb). I'd like to think if you have a state of the art decryption operation, they could at least spell whatsapp properly.
